item.title: Understanding Kubernetes Fundamentals
item.description:
Introduction

Kubernetes is an open-source container orchestration platform that automates the deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.

Core Concepts

Pods

Pods are the smallest deployable units in Kubernetes. They can contain one or more containers that share storage and network resources.

Services

Services provide stable networking endpoints for accessing pods. They enable load balancing and service discovery within the cluster.

Deployments

Deployments manage the desired state of your application, handling rolling updates and rollbacks automatically.

item.title: Essential DevOps Tools for 2026
item.description:
Version Control

Git remains the foundation of modern DevOps practices. GitHub, GitLab, and Bitbucket provide collaborative platforms built on Git.

CI/CD Pipelines

  • GitHub Actions: Integrated CI/CD with GitHub repositories
  • Jenkins: Flexible, open-source automation server
  • GitLab CI: Built-in CI/CD for GitLab projects

Container Orchestration

Kubernetes has become the industry standard for container orchestration, with managed services like EKS, GKE, and AKS simplifying deployment.

Infrastructure as Code

  • Terraform: Multi-cloud infrastructure provisioning
  • Ansible: Configuration management and automation
  • CloudFormation: AWS-native infrastructure as code

Monitoring and Observability

  • Prometheus: Metrics collection and alerting
  • Grafana: Visualization and dashboards
  • ELK Stack: Log aggregation and analysis

Conclusion

Mastering these tools provides a solid foundation for any DevOps engineer in 2026.

item.title: My Journey from QA to DevOps
item.description:
Starting in QA

My career began in Quality Assurance, where I developed strong testing skills and learned the importance of reliability and automation.

The Transition

The transition to DevOps was a natural evolution, combining my testing background with infrastructure and automation skills.

Key Skills Acquired

  • Linux Administration: Understanding system fundamentals
  • Scripting: Bash, Python for automation
  • CI/CD: Building automated testing and deployment pipelines
  • Containers: Docker and Kubernetes
  • Monitoring: Setting up observability tools

Challenges Faced

Learning infrastructure concepts while maintaining QA expertise required dedication and continuous learning.
